content.description: 35 ft of 5.fun.  No real crux obviously because it is a 5.5.  This is a great climb for the new climber.
content.protection: Cemented in bolts.  Little sketchy looking, but they seem to be pretty strong.
content.location: Last route on the far right side of the main wall.  Bolt anchor with Rap Chains.

climbs.name: We Refuse to Grow Old and/or Up

content.description: This is an easy but really fun route.  It too has some variety such as...  using the hueco-like friction holds instead of all the crimpers.  The crux section depends on how you want to send this route, whether or not you prefer finger destruction on crimps... (it's harder to use the friction holds to the left).
content.location: First bolt line to the right of King of Pain 5.9+

content.description: 2nd half of 1st pitch is runout w/ no pro.  Possible to go left for easier climbing and traverse right once approaching the anchor.
content.protection: Single rack / small nuts and cams - nothing bigger than #1 camalot
content.location: Left of the start of space ramp

content.description: An interesting climb that takes you on a tour of the main wall.  It traverses up and left on a shelf with a thin finger crack.  The shelf turns into a roof about half way up and the gear is a bit harder to place.
content.protection: Pro to #3 and bolts, rap anchor
content.location: It starts directly underneath the left side of the roof on the ramp and behind the oak tree.  The name says it all.

content.description: Starts off steep with some thin edges, then rolls over to some lower-angle climbing, then hits a short wall/ledge/roof. Pulling over the roof is a bit cruxy. Finishes on easier climbing.
content.location: The leftmost route on the main wall - the first route you get to at the end of the trail. From what I could tell, it angles up and a bit right and ends at the same anchor as Roll Over Beethoven.

content.description: This climb has a bit of variety.  It starts on a slight overhang then it's all face climbing after that.  If you want a real challenge, hit up Eagle's Talons (5.12) on the short face above your anchor.
content.location: Starts directly to the right of Icarus.  (It's the first bolted line to the right of the dihedral.)

content.description: Starts off steep on thin edges, rolls over to lower-angle climbing, crux is pulling over the wall/ledge/roof, and ends on easier climbing.
content.location: The second-from-the-left route at the leftmost side of Main Wall. At the top of the climbing trail, across from the big boulder. The leftmost route is Rusty Diamonds.

climbs.name: Into the Eye of the Son

content.description: This climb has it all.  It starts with good feet and small sloping crimpers and works up and left into great finger locks in a diagonal crack but the feet disappear.  Continue up onto thin face climbing with really athletic high-steps to the roof. Continue past roof to easier climbing, up and right to rap anchor.
content.location: start on the diagonal crack that jets up and left under the roof on the main wall

content.description: Located on the main wall in the prominent left-facing dihedral, this route is a feel-good climb with the lay-back finger crack (a good amount of these holds are slopers).  Save some energy because the crux section is at the top, after you traverse right out of the dihedral, you're high-stepping on crimpers to reach the anchor.

content.protection: Five bolts (one of the few non-cemented routes) with anchors at top.
content.location: Once you reach the main wall, you keep walking right. The only route with drilled bolts. You really can't miss it.
